summary.long: Ecclesiastes is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: The words of the Teacher, the son of David, king in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Utterly pointless,”
        says the Teacher.
“Absolutely pointless;
    everything is pointless.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What does a man gain
    from all of the work that he undertakes on earth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A generation goes,
    a generation comes,
        but the earth remains forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sun rises,
    the sun sets,
        then rushes back to where it arose.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The wind blows southward,
    then northward, constantly circulating,
        and the wind comes back again in its courses.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Everything is wearisome,
    more than man is able to express.
The eye is never satisfied by seeing,
    nor the ear by hearing.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Does anything exist about which someone might say,
    “Look at this! Is this new?”
It happened ages ago;
    it existed before we did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No one remembers those in the past,
    nor will they be remembered
        by those who come after them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I, the Teacher, have been king over Israel in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I dedicated myself to using wisdom for study and discovery of everything that is done under heaven. God uses terrible things so human beings will struggle with life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I observed every activity done on earth. My conclusion: all of it is pointless—like chasing after the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What is crooked cannot be made straight;
    what is not there cannot be counted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I told myself, “I have become greater and wiser than anyone who ruled before me in Jerusalem—yes, I have acquired a great deal of wisdom and knowledge.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I dedicated myself to learn about wisdom and knowledge, and about insanity and foolishness. And I discovered that this is also like chasing after the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: I told myself, “I will test you with pleasure, so enjoy yourself.” But this was pointless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Senseless,” said I concerning laughter and pleasure, “How practical is this?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I decided to indulge in wine, while still remaining committed to wisdom. I also tried to indulge in foolishness, just enough to determine whether it was good for human beings under heaven given the short time of their lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With respect to my extravagant works, I built houses for myself; I planted vineyards for myself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I constructed gardens and orchards for myself, and within them I planted all kinds of fruit trees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I built for myself water reservoirs to irrigate forests that produce trees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I acquired male and female slaves, and had other slaves born in my house. I also acquired for myself increasing numbers of herds and flocks—more than anyone who had lived before me in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I also accumulated silver, gold, and the wealth of kings and their kingdoms. I gathered around me both male and female singers, along with what delights a man—all sorts of mistresses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I became great, greater than anyone who had lived before me in Jerusalem. Throughout all of this, I remained wise.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever I wanted something I had seen, I never refused that desire. Instead, I enjoyed everything I did, and this became the reward in what I had undertaken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I examined all of my accomplishments that I had brought about by my own efforts, including the work that I had labored so hard to complete—and it was all pointless, like chasing after the wind, and there was nothing to be gained on earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next I turned to examine wisdom, insanity, and foolishness, because what can a person do who succeeds the king except what has already been accomplished?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I concluded that wisdom is more useful than foolishness, just as light is more useful than darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wise use their eyes, but the fool walks in darkness. I also perceived that the same outcome affects them all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I told myself, “Whatever happens to the fool will happen also to me. Therefore what’s the point in being so wise?” And I told myself that this also is pointless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For neither the wise nor the fool will be long remembered, since in days to come everything will be forgotten. The wise man dies the same way as the fool, does he not?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I hated life, because whatever is done on earth causes me trouble—it’s all pointless, like chasing after the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I despised everything I had worked for on earth, that is, the things that I will leave to the person who will succeed me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And who knows whether he will be wise or foolish? Either way, he will take possession of everything that I have done on earth, especially where I have excelled. This also is pointless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I came to be in despair about everything I had accomplished on earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For sometimes people who strive to obtain wisdom, knowledge, and equity leave everything as an inheritance to a person who never worked for it. This, too, is pointless and greatly troublesome.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For what does a person gain from everything that he accomplishes and from his inner life struggles that he undergoes while working on earth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, all of his days are filled with sorrow, and his struggles bring grief. In fact, his mind remains restless throughout the night. This is pointless, too!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The only worthwhile thing for a human being is to eat, drink, and enjoy life’s goodness that he finds in what he accomplishes. This, I observed, is also from the hand of God himself,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for who can eat or enjoy life apart from him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After all, to the person who is good in God’s sight, he gives wisdom, knowledge, and joy, but to the sinner he gives the troublesome task of acquiring and accumulating in order to leave it to someone who is good in the sight of God. This also is pointless and chasing after the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is a season for everything,
and a time for every event under heaven:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a time to be born, and a time to die;
    a time to plant, and a time to uproot what was planted;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a time to kill, and a time to heal;
    a time to tear down, and a time to build up;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a time to weep, and a time to laugh;
    a time to mourn, and a time to dance;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a time to scatter stones, and a time to gather stones;
    a time to embrace, and a time to refrain from embracing;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a time to search, and a time to give up searching;
    a time to keep, and a time to discard;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a time to tear, and a time to mend;
    a time to be silent, and a time to speak;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a time to love, and a time to hate;
    a time for war, and a time for peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What benefit does the worker gain from what he undertakes?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have observed the burdens placed by God on human beings in order to perfect them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made everything appropriate in its time. He also placed eternity within them—yet, no person can fully comprehend what God is doing from beginning to end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have concluded that the only worthwhile thing for them is to take pleasure in doing good in life;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: moreover, every person should eat, drink, and enjoy the benefits of everything that he undertakes, since it is a gift from God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have concluded that everything that God undertakes will last for eternity—nothing can be added to it nor taken away from it—and that God acts this way so that people will fear him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That which was, now is; and that which will be, already is; and God examines what has already taken place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I also examined on earth:
where the halls of justice were supposed to be,
    there was lawlessness;
and where the righteous were supposed to be,
    there was lawlessness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I told myself, “God will judge both the righteous and the wicked, because there is a time set to judge every event and every work.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “As for human beings,” I told myself, “God puts them to the test, that they might see themselves as mere animals.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For what happens to people also happens to animals—a single event happens to them: just as someone dies, so does the other. In fact, they all breathe the same way, so that a human being has no superiority over an animal. All of this is pointless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of them go to one place: all of them originate from dust, and all of them return to dust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who knows whether the spirit of human beings ascends, and whether the spirit of animals descends to the earth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I concluded that it is worthwhile for people to find joy in their accomplishments, because that is their inheritance, since who can see what will exist after them?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Next I turned to consider all kinds of oppression that exists on earth.
Look at the tears of the oppressed—
    there is no one to comfort them.
Power is on the side of their oppressors;
    so they have no comforters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I commended the dead who had already died as being happier than the living who are still alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Better than both of them is someone who has not yet been born, because he hasn’t experienced evil on earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I examined all sorts of work, including all kinds of excellent achievements that create envy in others. This also is pointless and chasing after the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fool crosses his arms and starves himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It’s better to have one handful of tranquility than to have two handfuls of trouble and to chase after the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I turned to re-examine something else that is pointless on earth:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Consider someone who is alone, having neither son nor brother. There is no end to all of his work, and he is never satisfied with wealth. “So for whom do I work,” he asks, “and deprive myself of pleasure?” This, too, is pointless and a terrible tragedy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two are better than one, because they have a good return for their labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If they stumble, the first will lift up his friend—but woe to anyone who is alone when he falls and there is no one to help him get up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again, if two lie close together, they will keep warm, but how can only one stay warm?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If someone attacks one of them, the two of them together will resist. Furthermore, the tri-braided cord is not soon broken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A poor but wise youth is better
    than an old but foolish king
        who will no longer accept correction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The former can come out of prison to reign,
    while the latter, even if born to kingship, may become poor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I observed everyone who lives and walks on earth, along with the youth who will take the king’s place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was no end to all of his subjects or to all of the people who had come before them. But those who come along afterward will not be happy with him. This is also pointless and a chasing after wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Watch your step whenever you visit God’s house, and come more ready to listen than to offer a fool’s sacrifice, since fools never think they’re doing evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Don’t be impulsive with your mouth
    nor be in a hurry to talk in God’s presence.
Since God is in heaven
    and you’re on earth,
        keep your speech short.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Too many worries lead to nightmares,
    and a fool is known from talking too much.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you make a promise to God, don’t fail to keep it, since he isn’t pleased with fools. Keep what you promise—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: it’s better that you don’t promise than that you do promise and not follow through.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Never let your mouth cause you to sin and don’t proclaim in the presence of the angel, “My promise was a mistake,” for why should God be angry at your excuse and destroy what you’ve undertaken?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In spite of many daydreams, pointless actions, and empty words, it is more important to fear God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t be surprised when you see the poor oppressed and the violent perverting both justice and verdicts in a province, for one high official watches another, and there are ones higher still over them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also, the increase of the land belongs to everyone; the king himself is served by his field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever loves money will never have enough money.
    Whoever loves luxury will not be content with abundance.
        This also is pointless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When possessions increase,
    so does the number of consumers;
therefore what good are they to their owners,
    except to look at them?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sweet is the sleep of a working man,
    whether he eats a little or a lot,
but the excess wealth of the rich
    will not allow him to rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have observed a painful tragedy on earth:
Wealth hoarded by its owner harms him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and that wealth is lost in troubled circumstances.
Then a son is born,
    but there is nothing left for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Just as he came naked from his mother’s womb,
    he will leave as naked as he came;
he will receive no profit from his efforts—
    he cannot carry away even a handful.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Furthermore, all his days he lives in darkness
    with great sorrow, anger, and affliction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look! I observed that it is good and prudent to eat, drink, and enjoy all that is good of a person’s work that he does on earth during the limited days of his life, which God gives him, for this is his allotment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, for every person to whom God has given wealth, riches, and the ability to enjoy them, to accept this allotment, and to rejoice in his work—this is a gift from God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For he will not brood much over the days of his life, since God will keep him occupied with the joys of his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There exists another misfortune that I have observed on earth, and it is a heavy burden upon human beings:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: a man to whom God gives wealth, riches, and honor, so that he lacks none of his heart’s desires—but God does not give him the capability to enjoy them. Instead, a stranger consumes them. This is pointless and a grievous affliction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A man might father a hundred children, and live for many years, so that the length of his life is long—but if his life does not overflow with goodness, and he doesn’t receive a proper burial, I maintain that stillborn children are better off than he is,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because stillborn children arrive in pointlessness, leave in darkness, and their names are covered in darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, though they never saw the sun nor learned anything, they are more content than the other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even if he lives a thousand years twice over without experiencing the best—aren’t all of them going to the same place?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Every person works for his own self-interests,
    but his desires remain unsatisfied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For what advantage has the wise person over the fool?
    What advantage does the poor man have
        in knowing how to face life?
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Because many words lead to pointlessness,
    how do people benefit from this?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who knows what is best for people in this life, every day of their pointless lives that they pass through like a shadow? Who informs people on earth what will come along after them?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A good name exceeds the value of fine perfume,
    and the day of someone’s death exceeds the value of the day of his birth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It’s better to attend a funeral
    than to attend a banquet,
for everyone dies eventually,
    and the living will take this to heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sorrow is better than laughter,
    because the heart is made better through trouble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For the wise person thinks carefully when in mourning,
    but fools focus their thoughts on pleasure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is better to listen to a wise person’s rebuke
    than to listen to the praise of fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For as thorns burn to heat a pot,
    so also is the laughter of the fool—
        even this is pointless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Unjust gain makes the wise foolish,
    and a bribe corrupts the heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The conclusion of something is better than its beginning,
    and a patient attitude is more valuable than a proud one.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Never be in a hurry to become internally angry,
    since anger settles down in the lap of fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Never ask “Why does the past seem so much better than now?”
    because this question does not come from wisdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wise use of possessions is good;
    it brings benefit to the living.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Indeed, wisdom gives protection, just like money does,
    but it’s better to know that wisdom gives life,
        to those who have mastered it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Consider the work of God:
Who is able to straighten
    what he has bent?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When times are good, be joyful;
    when times are bad, consider this:
God made the one as well as the other,
    so people won’t seek anything outside of his best.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have seen it all during my pointless life:
both a righteous person who dies
    while he is righteous,
and a wicked person who lives to an old age,
    while remaining wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be overly righteous,
    nor be overly wise.
        Why be self-destructive?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not excel at wickedness,
    nor be a fool.
        Why die before your time?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is good for you to grab hold of this and not let go,
    because whoever fears God will escape
        all of these extremes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wisdom given as strength to a wise person
    is better than having ten powerful men in the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For there is not a single righteous man on earth
    who practices good and does not sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Don’t listen to everything that is spoken—
    you may hear your servant cursing you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
since you also know how often
    you have cursed others.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I used my wisdom to test all of this.
I said, “I want to be wise,”
    but it was beyond me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whatever it is,
    it’s far off and most profound.
        Who can attain it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I committed myself to understand,
        to learn, to search for wisdom and explanations,
and to understand both the evil that is foolishness
    and the stupidity that is delusion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I discovered for myself a bitterness
    that surpasses that of death:
the woman whose heart is full of snares and nets,
    whose hands are chains of bondage.
Whoever pleases God will escape from her,
    but the transgressor will be trapped by her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Look at this,” says the Teacher. “Linking one thing to another, I reached this conclusion:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Among the things I seek but have not found:
    one man among a thousand I did find,
        but I have not found one woman to be wise among all these.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have discovered only this:
    God made human beings for righteousness,
        but they seek many alternatives.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who is really wise?
Who knows how to interpret this saying:
“A person’s wisdom improves his appearance,
    softening a harsh countenance.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I advise doing what the king says, especially regarding an oath to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t be in a hurry to leave him, and don’t persist in evil, for he does whatever he pleases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since a king’s command is powerful, who is able to challenge him, asking, “What are you doing?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoever obeys his commands will not experience harm, and the wise in heart will discern both the appropriate time and response.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, there is an appropriate time and a response for every circumstance, since human misery weighs heavily upon him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For he has absolutely no knowledge what will happen, since who can declare to him when it will come about?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just as no human being has control over the wind to restrain it, so also no human being has control over the day of his death. Just as no one is discharged during war, so wickedness will not release those who practice it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I observed all this, and carefully considered everything that is undertaken on earth, especially the time when someone dominates another to his detriment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I watched the wicked being entombed. They used to come in and out of the Holy Place, but now they are forgotten in the city, where they used to work. This, too, is pointless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever a sentence for a crime is not carried out swiftly, the human mind becomes determined to commit evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even though a sinner does what is wrong a hundred times and still survives, nevertheless I also know that things will go well for those who fear God, who fear in his presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But things will not go well for the wicked person: he will not lengthen his life like a shadow, since he has no fear before God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Here is a pointless thing that happens on earth: A righteous man receives what happens to the wicked, and a wicked man receives what happens to the righteous. I concluded that this, too, is pointless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So then I recommended enjoyment of life, because it is better on earth for a man to eat, drink, and be happy, since this will stay with him throughout his struggle all the days of his life, which God grants him on earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I dedicated myself to experience wisdom and to observe what is undertaken on earth—even going without sleep day and night—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I saw all of it as the activity of God. Frankly, a human being cannot understand what happens on earth, because however hard a man works to discover it, he will not find out. Despite what he thinks he knows, he will not be able to figure it out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In light of all of this, I committed myself to explain it this way: the righteous and the wise, along with everything they do, are in the hands of God. Furthermore, as to love and hate, no human being knows everything concerning them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Everyone shares the same experience: a single event affects the righteous, the wicked, the good, the clean, the unclean, whoever sacrifices, and whoever does not sacrifice.
As it is with the good person,
    so also it is with the sinner;
as it is with someone who takes an oath,
    so also it is with someone who fears taking an oath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is a tragedy that infects everything that happens on earth: a common event happens to everyone. In fact, the hearts of human beings are full of evil. Madness remains in their hearts while they live, and afterwards they join the dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “While someone is among the living, hope remains,” because “it is better to be a living dog than to be a dead lion.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At least the living know they will die,
    but the dead know nothing;
they no longer have a reward,
    since memory about them has been forgotten.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Furthermore, their love, their hate, and their envy
    have been long lost.
Never again will they have a part
    in what happens on earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go ahead and enjoy your meals as you eat. Drink your wine with a joyful attitude, because God already has approved your actions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Always keep your garments white, and don’t fail to anoint your head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Find joy in living with your wife whom you love every day of your pointless life that God gave you on earth, because this is your life assignment and your work to do on earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whatever the activity in which you engage, do it with all your ability, because there is no work, no planning, no learning, and no wisdom in the next world where you’re going.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I considered and observed on earth the following:
The race doesn’t go to the swift,
    nor the battle to the strong,
nor food to the wise,
    nor wealth to the smart,
nor recognition to the skilled.
    Instead, timing and circumstances meet them all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In addition, no human being knows his time:
Like fish captured in a cruel net,
    or as birds caught in a snare,
so also are human beings caught by bad timing
    that surprises them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I also observed this example of wisdom on earth, and it seemed important to me:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a little city with few men in it. A great king came against it, surrounded it, and built massive siege ramps against it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now there was found within it a poor, but wise man. He delivered the city by his wisdom, but not one person remembered that poor man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I concluded, “Wisdom is better than strength. Nevertheless, the wisdom of the poor is rejected—his words are never heard.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The softly spoken words of the wise are to be heard
    rather than the shouts of a ruler of fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wisdom is better than weapons of war,
    and a single sinner can destroy a lot of good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As dead flies cause the perfumer’s ointment to stink,
so also does a little foolishness to one’s reputation of wisdom and honor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A wise man’s heart tends toward his right,
    but a fool’s heart tends toward his left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Furthermore, the way a fool lives shows he has no sense;
    he proclaims to everyone that he’s a fool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If your overseer gets angry at you, don’t resign,
    because calmness pacifies great offenses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Here’s another tragedy that I’ve observed on earth,
    a kind of error that comes from an overseer:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Foolishness is given great honor,
    while the prosperous sit in lowly places.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And I have observed servants riding on horses,
    while princes walk on the ground like servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever digs a pit may fall into it,
    and whoever breaks through a wall
        may suffer a snake bite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Someone who quarries stone might be injured;
    someone splitting logs can fall into danger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If someone’s ax is blunt—the edge isn’t sharpened—
    then more strength will be needed.
        Putting wisdom to work will bring success.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If a serpent strikes despite being charmed,
    there’s no point in being a snake charmer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The words spoken by the wise are gracious,
    but the lips of a fool will devour him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He begins his speech with foolishness,
    and concludes it with evil madness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The fool overflows with words,
    and no one can predict what will happen.
As to what will happen after him,
    who can explain it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The work of a fool so wears him out
    that he can’t even find his way to town.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Woe to the land whose king is a youth
    and whose princes feast in the morning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That land is blessed whose king is of noble birth,
    whose princes feast at the right time,
        for strength, and not to become drunk.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Through slothfulness the roof deteriorates,
    and a house leaks because of idleness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Festivals are for laughter,
    wine makes life pleasant,
        and money speaks to everything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not curse the king,
    even in your thoughts.
Do not curse the rich,
    even in your bedroom.
For a bird will fly by and tell what you say,
    or something with wings may talk about it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Spread your bread on the water—
after a while you will find it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Apportion what you have into seven, or even eight parts,
    because you don’t know what disaster might befall the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever keeps staring at the wind won’t sow;
    whoever daydreams won’t reap.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Just as you do not understand the way of the spirit
    in the womb of a pregnant mother,
so also you do not know
    what God is doing in everything he makes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sow your seed in the morning,
    and don’t stop working until evening,
since you don’t know which of your endeavors will do well,
    whether this one or that,
        or even if both will do equally well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How sweet is the daylight, and how pleasant it is for someone’s eyes to behold the sunshine!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even if a person lives many years, let him enjoy them all, recalling that there will be many days of darkness to come—all of which are pointless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So enjoy yourself in your youth, young man, and be encouraged during your younger days. Live as you like, consistent with your world view, but keep in mind that God will bring you to account for everything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Banish sorrow from your heart, and evil from your body, since both childhood and the prime of life are pointless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So remember your Creator during your youth!
Otherwise, troublesome days will come
and years will creep up on you when you’ll say,
        “I find no pleasure in them,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Otherwise, when the sun, daylight, moon, or stars turn dark,
    or when clouds fail to return after the rain—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when that day comes, the palace guards will tremble,
    strong men will stoop down,
women grinders will cease because they are few,
    and the sight of those who peer through the lattice will grow dim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The doors to the street will be shut
    when the sound of grinding decreases,
when one wakes up at the song of a bird,
    and all of the singing women are silenced.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At that time they will fear climbing heights
    and dangers along the road
while the almond tree will blossom,
    and the grasshopper is weighed down.
Desire will cease,
    because the person goes to his eternal home,
        and mourners will gather in the marketplace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the silver cord is severed,
    the golden vessel is broken,
the pitcher is shattered at the fountain,
    and the wheel is broken at the cistern,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then man’s dust will go back to the earth,
    returning to what it was,
        and the spirit will return to the God who gave it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Utterly pointless,” says the Teacher.
    “Everything is pointless.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moreover, besides being wise himself, the Teacher taught people what he had learned by listening, making inquiries, and composing many proverbs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Teacher searched to find appropriate expressions, and what is written here is right and truthful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sayings from the wise are like cattle prods and well fastened nails; this masterful collection was given by one shepherd.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So learn from them, my son. There is no end to the crafting of many books, and too much study wearies the body.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let the conclusion of all of these thoughts be heard: 
Fear God and obey his commandments,
    for this is what it means to be human.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For God will judge every deed,
    along with every secret,
        whether good or evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator
